betterquesting:10.desc:8:
NEI recipe search got improved even further!

Select a search mode extended+ to try it out!

Here backticks `` are used around the search queries. You don't need them when searching.

By default the search works like in the extended mode, searching in §lany§r of the inputs and outputs of a recipe. So if you search a recipe by `§1-§rdust`, it would return all the recipes where there's at least one item that doesn't have §o"dust"§r.

Let's say you want to search only in §linputs§r. Put §a<§r before your search query to do that! For example `§a<§riron` returns all the recipes with §o"iron"§r in one of the §linputs§r, `§a<§rsteel§5@gregtech§r` returns the recipes with at least one item from mods, containing §9Gregtech§r in their name, with §o"steel"§r.

But then, if you search by `§a<§1-§rdust` it still returns the recipes with §o"dust"§r on the left. Why is that? Because §a<§r searches among §lany§r items. So if there's one item that doesn't have §o"dust"§r, then it would still match the recipe, even if the rest of the inputs are dusts.

To solve this use §a<&§r instead. Like this: `§a<&§1-§rdust`. It returns §lall§r the recipes without §o"dust"§r among the inputs! §a<&§r sets a §lstrict§r condition on §lall§r inputs, unlike §a<§r that sets a condition on §lany§r input.

To filter the §loutputs§r use §a>§r and §a>&§r. They work the same way, but allow you to filter the §loutputs§r of a recipe. So `§a>§rgold` gives you the recipes with at least one §loutput§r with §o"gold"§r. And `§a>&§rgold` gives you the recipes with §o"gold"§r in every outputted item.

Want to combine multiple conditions? Sure, just put them one after another in any order. E.g. you could search for `§a<§riron§a>§rsteel`, `§a<&§r §1-§b$dust§r §a<§r cell`, `§a>&§1-§rdust cell`.

Or even for `dust§a>§rcell`. Here the non-prefixed part works like default, searching among §lany§r items from the inputs or outputs. So this query returns the recipes with §o"dust"§r in one of the inputs or outputs and §o"cell"§r in one of the outputs.

In some recipes you might have items that don't belong to inputs or outputs. In order to filter them use `§a^§r` and `§a^&§r` respectively.

You could add spaces for readability too, because (unless you have space mode on) spaces could be used anywhere while in extended+ mode.
